Award.AwardTitle: Photochemical Strategies with Supramolecular Assistance to Monitor Cellular Dynamics in Living Organism
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims at the design and preparation of molecules that can be transported to target locations in organisms and emit light only after stimulation with an activating optical beam. Subsequent detection of the emitted light offers the opportunity to locate the position of the activated molecules in a sample of interest and follow their movements in real time. These light emitters can ultimately become analytical tools for biological studies, such as the tracking of moving cells during the growth of the organism, and contribute valuable insights on organismal development. These fundamental studies in chemistry may have implications in biology and medicine. Additionally, the activities teach the participating undergraduate and graduate students how to prepare molecules from commercial reagents, characterize their structures and investigate their interactions with light. Furthermore, they contribute to strengthening an existing educational collaboration between the laboratory of the principal investigator at the University of Miami and a faculty member of Miami-Dade College. This collaboration exposes high-school and undergraduate students to research. Considering that both institutions have minority enrollments in excess of 50%, these training opportunities may have a significant educational impact on members of underrepresented groups.

The goal of this research is the development of biocompatible probes with photoactivatable fluorescence in the deep-red and near-infrared regions of the electromagnetic spectrum. Specifically, this project involves the synthesis of molecules incorporating a fluorescent borondipyrromethene chromophore and a photoswitchable oxazine auxochrome, together with their photochemical/photophysical characterization and incorporation within polymer nanoparticles. Upon illumination at an appropriate activation wavelength, the photoinduced and irreversible opening of the oxazine heterocycle of these compounds is expected to extend the electronic conjugation of the adjacent borondipyrromethene chromophore. This structural transformation is designed to bathochromically shift the main absorption band of the latter component and allow its selective excitation at a suitable wavelength with concomitant fluorescence. On the basis of these operating principles, the translocation of the photochemical and emissive product, across a given sample of interest, can then be probed in real time with the sequential acquisition of fluorescence images. These light emitters can ultimately become analytical tools for biological studies, such as the tracking of moving cells during the growth of the organism, and contribute valuable insights on organismal development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Our research activities led to the identification of: (1) a viable mechanism to activate bright far-red fluorescence with infinite contrast under the influence of mild visible illumination; (2) a structural design for the assembly of supramolecular nanocarriers capable of transporting a fluorescent cargo into aqueous environments with no detrimental effects on its photophysical properties; (3) a convenient experimental protocol to deliver fluorescent probes in live cells, embryos and nematodes.  These achievements together will, ultimately, translate into the ability to monitor dynamic events in vivo with no cytotoxic effects on a given biological preparation under investigation.  Indeed, the examples of photoactivatable fluorophores emerged from these studies have an unprecedented combination of photochemical and photophysical properties that allow the implementation of innovative bioimaging schemes.  The further optimization of these systems will, presumably, lead to an entire family of switchable probes for bioimaging protocols that would, otherwise, be impossible to perform with the sole aid of conventional fluorophores.  Additionally, our studies led also to the development of innovative operating principles to probe pH and temperature with ratiometric fluorescence measurements.  The resulting pH-sensitive and thermosensitive fluorophores do not suffer from the concentration effects and optical artifacts that instead limit existing systems and allow the convenient mapping of pH and temperature distributions with spatial resolution at the micrometer level.

Broader Impact: Our fundamental studies contributed an innovative structural design to implement photochromic transformations with unprecedented performance that, eventually, evolved into an entire family of photoresponsive molecular switches.  These findings are now well recognized within the broad international community of photochemists and are especially significant to the many investigators interested in photochromism.  In fact, other research groups are now developing stimuli-responsive molecules and functional materials based on the photoswitchable heterocyclic scaffold originally devised in our laboratories.  In addition to having already stimulated investigations within their immediate field of study, our research activities are also expected to have profound implications in biology and medicine.  Indeed, our mechanisms to activate fluorescence, under the influence of light, pH or temperature, offer the opportunity to implement innovative imaging schemes that would be impossible to perform with conventional fluorescent probes.  Specifically, our activatable fluorophores allow: (1) the visualization of cellular substructures with spatial resolution at the nanometer level; (2) the selective detection of cancer cells with infinite contrast; (3) the real-time monitoring of dynamic events in vivo for prolonged periods of time with no toxic effects; (4) the visualization of pH and temperature distributions with spatial resolution at the micrometer level.  Thus, our switchable molecular probes can evolve into invaluable analytical tools for a diversity of bioimaging applications and can have a long-term impact on biomedical research.

The results emerged from our research program translated into 27 research articles, 24 invited lectures at international conferences and 20 invited seminars at other academic institutions.  Our research activities also contributed to the training of 18 undergraduate (3 African Americans, 11 Hispanics, 10 Women) and 6 graduate (2 Women) students as well as 1 postdoctoral associate.  5 of the undergraduate students (4 Hispanics, 3 Women) were recruited through an on-going educational program developed in collaboration with a faculty member of Miami Dade College.  They worked in the laboratories of the principal investigator for an entire summer and, as a result of their direct exposure to a research environment that is not available at Miami Dade College, eventually transferred to the University of Miami and, after graduation, enrolled into biochemistry or chemistry graduate programs of other institutions in the state of Florida.  The experimental work of our graduate students and postdoctoral associate demanded extensive electrochemical, imaging and spectroscopic analyses, in addition to a predominant synthetic component.  Furthermore, the participating personnel was exposed to collaborations with domestic and foreign research groups at the interface of biology and chemistry.
